threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format and ideally smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking.
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the Catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads).

Do not want:
• Go to /wsr/ or /r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

Want to learn more?
• The /p/ Wiki

I carry mine around all the time. It's like 3 pounds with its heaviest lens. The only time I need a case is if I'm bringing a tripod/extra lenses/a flash. Larger cameras seem like a big deal if you wear your sling like a necklace instead of a sling. The real advantage of a tiny camera is being able to use flimsy ass 8/12 section travel tripods so you can fit everything you need for long exposures in two coat pockets (which you don't do because that makes your coat weird and unbalanced and it's not very secure). But the K1s shake reduction and horizon correction are so good I can usually handhold or set it on a rock or something.

but if I had a more basic nikon I'd probably have bought a snoy by now. definitely not a fuji. for the prices they charge i'd rather buy a full frame MILC or a M43 for MUH ZOOOOOOOM

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Halloween Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4085831

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

threads.com:
I'm gonna make a thread for this little project I've had going for a while.
I became fascinated by taking photos of different Asian dishes (mostly Chinese and Indonesian) in black and white. I found the lack of colour really let me focus on texture, context, light, reflections and how to find new ways to make very similar photos feel distinct and different from each other.

So yeah, here are some noodle photos I've taken for you to enjoy. If you have any questions about the food itself, or about anything else, go ahead and shoot.

last_replies.name: giannis
last_replies.com:
>>4103384
>3d pop is staging and composition
This is the "issue", as long as 3d pop is not defined into something measurable, it just becomes cognitive dissonance and conformation bias about a thousand different things a person things they're seeing.

In the past, WWII and a bit before, Ι guess it described the different design philosophies between Leica and Zeiss.
Leica went for high resolution (higher 40lp/mm (and up) curve in the MTF chart) at the expense of contrast, while Zeiss went for higher contrast (higher 5-10lp/mm curve in the MTF) at the expense of resolution.

These different philosophies came with side effects, especially before modern coatings.
For Leica it meant using more lens groups (and hence glass-to-air surfaces), which meant lower contrast and more flaring.
For Zeiss it meant using as few lens groups as possible, which meant asymmetric designs with more field curvature.
The first look came to be known as the Leica "glow", the second as the Zeiss "3D pop".

Imo, all irrelevant today, cause after coatings, asphericals and CAD, everybody went for max resolution *and* max contrast *and* minimum field curvature at the same time, using the same basic optical formulas, with minimal differences between manufacturers wrt to lenses of the same caliber.

So my take is all that bullshit is mostly irrelevant today and used as autistic purchase rationalisations for expensive lenses.

The only thing I can "justify" as """"3D pop"""" is field curvature (throwing everything off centre out of focus), paired with a very high contrast and high res centre, and maybe quick drop off of the MTF as you move behind the focus point.
But that's quite measurable and no mainstream modern lens behaves like that.

threads.name: Zach
threads.com:
Okay if light is traveling all over the place and it is clear and colored, why doesn't it look as trippy as pic related?

[EXIF data available. Click here to show/hide.]
Camera-Specific Properties:
Image-Specific Properties:
Image OrientationUnknown

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4103113
>>4103115
anon is correct. the lens in your eye ball focuses light to the retina (although it struggles with higher wavelengths so blue and violet are never actually in focus but it's close enough for your brain to cope and compensate).

when light is traveling through air it's generally all wavelengths which we are not particularly sensitive to in terms of colour, only as luminance. when it strikes an object of a certain colour or pigment it means that object absorbs all the wavelengths that aren't the colour but reflects wavelenghts that are that colour. your pupil is narrow enough that scattered reflections don't get to your retina, only the reflections that are arriving more directly to the pupil, further focused by the lens in your eye. this is why peripheral vision is always out of focus even if you try to draw your attention to it, and also why technically your eye is only ever focused on a single pinpoint but your visual system is quite adept at making you feel as though you are grasping the whole scene in front of you, largely through central nervous system processing and constant micro glances to scan the scene in front of you.

fun fax: the very center of our vision has very slow response to movement and sees absolutely nothing but color (i.e. no contrast at all) but it is the only part of our vision that is actually in focus. the periphery of our vision is extremely sensitive to movement and is biased toward contrast and sees very little color. in reality our vision is incredibly weak and dull in relationship to many of our animal cousins.

during scotopic vision (when your eyes are adjusted to seeing in low light) you are completely blind to whatever you look directly at. if you want to have a look at something, you have to glance away slightly and it'll appear in your peripheral vision, and never in focus. the extreme sensitivity to movement that we experience in our peripheral vision is what kept us from getting ate by the dinosaurs.

>>4100518

I actually use one of those cell phone repair kits that comes with a screwdriver and like 100 bits.

Get a set of lens spanners, very small set of slip jaw pliers like Channel locks but very tiny. You'll want some assorted lubricants that are camera specific, I use Japan Hobby Tool. Believe it or not, Cera Vie blue bottle works good too. It's a hand moisturizer. You'll also want a set of lens filter straighteners, looks like a vice.

You'll want some small metal and plastic brushes. A tooth brush. Retractable magnet wand.

Maybe this week I'll post my setup.

threads.sub: I bought a Canon R10 - Did I make a mistake?
threads.com:
So 5-6 years ago I purchased a Canon 6D with a "nifty fifty" as well as a 35mm Sigma Art f/1.4 lens. It cost me about $2000, which was a lot of money for me at the time (especially since I'm only a hobby photographer).

Anyway, I wanted to upgrade to a mirrorless camera due to its better autofocusing system etc, so after a lot of reading (I was mostly researching full frame cameras), I ended up ordering an APS-C camera (the Canon R10).

My thinking was, due to the 1.6x crop factor, my 50mm would become an 80mm lens and my 35mm Sigma would become 56mm. And I wanted a lens in this region for portrait photography.

But now I hear that just attaching one of these full frame lenses via an EF to RF mount, could actually make the IQ worse.

Did I make a mistake buying a cropped sensor camera? Especially since I mostly do portrait photography nowadays? Should I have just sold everything I had and started fresh with a full-frame Sony or Nikon?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101136
Sensor size isn’t a meme if you compare over larger distances, like MFT to FF. If you are anything but a fair weather person the boost in dynamic range and better noise to signal ratio is noticeable then. APSC to FF and FF to MF? Bet money and tell me which prints came from which camera. Many have failed at a rate equal to a coin flip. APSC to MF? You could probably tell. When you push them to the extremes of shitty light and high dynamic range in one exposure it gets obvious even APSC to FF but night photographers are a minority and many of them appreciate a compressed lofi look.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>4100996

What? What are you taking pictures of? Any examples?

If it's still photography, you can either use live view and zoom focus, or you can use the rangefinder with the AI FOCUS acquisition and then recompose. Otherwise you should be able to do just fine with AI FOCUS and fast shutter speed.

I don't have this issue why using a kiss body, so you shouldn't really have issues with a 6D.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Use an old film lens (the rendering style, color cast, and softness are part of the look)
Use a glimmerglass filter (softens highlights... and detail)
Totally kill color noise at the cost of sharpness, leave luminance noise, maybe even increase it.
Shoot in soft natural lighting or git gud. Artificial light, especially flash, was difficult for most people to use for the longest time, so most film shots are either in very good light or ambient light.
Use a fixed white balance. Use a fixed ISO instead of coping and using it and EV values to fix exposures. This is a stylistic choice but the result is film-y thematic consistency shot to shot.

editing is arguably the most important aspect of photography. no matter how interesting your subject, composition, and the overall context of your work is, it must have striking contrast, colors, and other things. I mean if you want to be a few inches away from your model and still capture a large portion of them then you're gonna have to go somewhat wide. Unless you mean minimum focus distance, in which case on the 16-55 for example is 30cm, on primes like the 18/1.4 and 23/1.4 about 20cm, the 30/2.8 macro can do 10cm. Remember those figures are from the sensor plane, so the 30/2.8 for example has a minimum working distance of about 1.2cm (from the surface of the lens).

The easiest way really is just taking whatever you shoot on FF and dividing that by 1.52. 50mm FF=33mm Fuji, 35mm FF=23mm Fuji, 24mm FF=16mm Fuji. You'll get the same field of view that way. Like >>4099416 and >>4099235 said, you won't run into problems unless you go really really wide, where you'll still find lenses (the 8-16/2.8 for example) but they're basically as expensive as their FF counterparts.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: How does one improve the look of eyelids in portraits? Not asking for postprocessing tips, I want to get it right on camera.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Shoot with the sun shining at an oblique angle into the eyelid for darker eyes, for lighter eyes you can also get away with diffuse light like on an overcast day. Stop down the lens to f/4-5.6, and make sure that your camera is focusing on the eyelid, not into the eyelashes or into reflections in the eye. Shoot at a higher shutter speed than usual. Try to minimize reflections. As for contrast, color and sharpening, that depends on your camera and workflow.

last_replies.com:
>>4101798
These telescoping tripods aren't usable for heavy cameras. I have a prinz one with steel legs and it's clearly unstable and leaning/bending with a light film SLR and anything heavier than a short prime. You would want a general tripod collar for anything more front heavy. With the legs collapsed, they make good tabletop mounts for small spotting scopes, and are usable for very light and well balanced camera setups but nothing bigger. I keep mine in my range bag and use it to hold up phones for phonetography if those are the cameras that are available.

>>4100119
"cross eye" refers to the direction your eyes are pointing crossing paths with one-another, rather than the normal case of them both pointing at the same place
basically you want to look "in front" of the screen, rather than at the screen
if you don't know how to control your eyes to adjust where they're looking on demand, try putting your finger in front if your face, looking at your finger, then moving your finger to and from the screen until you have 3 of the picture you're looking at (instead of 2), then shift your focus from the finger to the centre picture, if you can focus on the centre picture, it will be in stereo, because each eye will be looking at different pictures (left eye on the right picture, right eye on the left picture, crossed)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101651
note that you will need to line things up so the centre picture is as clear as you can make it, poorly overlapping/correlating pictures may cause your eyes to try to snap back to looking at the screen normally, as your brain will recognise two badly-overlapping images as meaning you're not focusing correctly

2, you obsess over made up subjective bullshit, ranging from "3d pop" to "magic CCD colors" to "leica look", etc.

If you are buying a nice camera with the goal of making prints, you should be inclined to buy a nice lens on the basis of its specs, because you are not going to be able to tell if you take the output of each lens and scale them down to blog size.
Likewise if you are buying an expensive camera with the goal of low light photography you might want to look at the noise charts rather than okay-light SOOC jpeg snapshits scaled down to blog size.

But if you are not spending a lot of money and just want to take generic photos it's not such a big deal

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4099579
It actually depends on the viewing device. Small resolution jpegs on high res phone screens, for example, will look worse than png of the same resolution. TV screens are guilty of this as well. They see low res jpeg and loves to throw scaling algorithms over it. With png they must at least obey baked in colour space. This goes for 8bit png, 24bit tends to be overkill in most cases, but can be used as means of getting rid of banding.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Is conventional advice for beginner gear fundamentally wrong?
threads.com:
Is conventional beginner gear advice not just wrong but even one of the leading causes of GAS?

A lot of people are being led to believe that focal length is a lot more important than it really is. Which is somewhat natural, it's a lot more intuitive than something like f-numbers.

So usually you will start with the kit 18-55mm on APS-C. Then you add a similarly lacklustre tele zoom and a wide zoom. Or a superzoom. Or maybe several low quality primes, someone told you they were sharper. And now you've gone and spent quite a bit of money and have more choices than you know what to do with. And none of them are weather sealed, so that limits how much you can actually be out and shoot. And when you do you have tons of chromatic aberration, distortion, high ISO noise, cluttered ultra-wide scenes and hazy ultra-long ones. It's just not fun anymore. So you try to fill the void with even more gear that you don't know what to do with, if you haven't financially ruined yourself yet.

Why not instead get just one really stellar lens from the start and stick with it? Maybe a constant f2.8 standard zoom, or a fast prime somewhere in that range. You can always get more later when you have the skill set to make use of them, but a lot of the great masters went their whole career with just one or two lenses, or lenses no more extreme than what is found in the said standard zoom, and it didn't hold back any of them.

What do you guys think, is it time to fundamentally reconsider what we tell beginners about what gear to get? What advice would you have wanted to hear before getting your first serious camera?

threads.com:
Mt. Erebus (Antarctica), 1955. Just look at this shit. If someone were to take a picture like this on a digital camera it would be called overprocessed dogshit but here it is. I don't know what my point is but every once in a while I come across a great old analog pic and I just think: why can't digital look like that? Well, maybe it can, we're just afraid to make it happen.
For example many analog snaps are super duper warm. On digi cams we put "auto white balance" but that's bullshit, back in the days a roll of film had just 1 white balance whether it was sunny or cloudy or you were inside a fluorescent lit office. So what if you'd just fix your white balance on "overcast" and stop giving a shit that your pixels aren't perfectly averaged to xxxx kelvin? Just saying.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101063
>Well, maybe it can, we're just afraid to make it happen.
sometimes this is definitely the case. part of the film look is very high contrast, or lack of detail, et cetera. however, this isn't a constant. there are plenty of film photos that are characterized by their low contrast instead, and plenty that posess great levels of detail. yet they're still recognizable as film photos. this is why film is so difficult to emulate. you can apply a fixed effect to an image but that just isn't good enough.
>For example many analog snaps are super duper warm. On digi cams we put "auto white balance" but that's bullshit, back in the days a roll of film had just 1 white balance whether it was sunny or cloudy or you were inside a fluorescent lit office. So what if you'd just fix your white balance on "overcast" and stop giving a shit that your pixels aren't perfectly averaged to xxxx kelvin?
I've tried this. since most films were daylight balanced, I've tried just fixing the white balance to daylight and using that. but the strange thing is, film seems to behave differently than digital with white balance. a shot taken in a given set of conditions on film will end up looking far more color accurate than a digital shot taken in the same circumstances with the white balance set to daylight. the digital shot will very rapidly end up looking extremely inaccurate: either much too warm or much too cool. I don't know why this is.
I encourage you to try this yourself. you'll see the strange difference. it even holds for indoor shots. film photos will look warm, yes, but nowhere near the clownishly yellow results you'll get from shooting daylight white balance indoors under artificial light with digital.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101063
it's an unedited amateur snapshot. you can do this on digital. you just don't want to because you have the option not to.

digital just brought darkroom fuckery and formerly expensive techniques to the masses. you must understand that a lot of professional film shooters had interchangeable backs with different film stocks, identical cameras with different film stocks - not just for white balance and color cast, but also for ISO sensitivtity. push this roll two stops, pull that roll two stops. now you can do this on a per image basis...

but you can still just leave the ISO at 400 all day, leave the white balance on a fixed setting, and shoot jpegs if you want to.

pros used to take their developed film and enlarge them optically. during this process they would edit the white balance and color balance with filters between the negative/slide and the larger film, and burn and dodge the enlargement to darken highlights and bring out shadows. just like sing LIGHTroom. but it was called the darkroom. digital did nothing more than make this an affordable process that didn't involve sensitive film stocks, expensive, toxic chemistry, pricey enlargers, and a whole room dedicated to it....

but you can always go old school and just take your walmart 1 hour photo equivalents (SOOC jpegs) and enjoy them as is.

you might as well say "zooms bad because you only need one focal length" meanwhile pros used to have a camera with each prime hanging from their neck

I shoot mainly event photography at 'alternative events', very frequently wth poor or moody lighting, so low light performance and noise quality is important to me. I am a huge raw processing / color calibration geek, so I basically don't care at all about how images look SOOC.

Yes, I know that it's the photographer and not the gear and all that, but also I'm looking at spending quite a bit of money and buying into an ecosystem here so I'd like to consider my options carefully.

>>4100265
>muh strong cfa!
The irony of this claim is that color accuracy went up with newer, weaker CFAs. The problem wasn't RGB separation, it was noise, and a weaker CFA reduces noise.

>>4100492
Old CCDs are closer to slides because they have less dynamic range like slides. If you want to emulate slides, pull the exposure down and let some of the shadows/highlights go in post.
